question: A glioma is the most common tumor in which of the following cases?

answers.option: Primary brain tumor in the elderly

question: Which of the following can be found in the brain in neurosarcoidosis?
What antibodies are involved in myasthenia gravis?
Negri bodies are a histopathological finding in which of the following conditions?
Acute bacterial meningitis will have which of the following findings?
Which of the following cells are involved in the pathophysiology of neurosarcoidosis?
What is the most common causative organism of meningitis in young adults?
What basal exudate will be seen in tuberculous meningitis?
Which of the following rarely occurs in Friedreich's ataxia?
Which of the following best describes the difference between Arnold Chiari I and II malformations?

answers.option: Type I is associated with meningomyelocele and type II is not
Type II is often a silent abnormality but type I is not
Type II presents in adolescence while type I presents in infancy
Type I is less severe than type II
Type I has respiratory distress and type II does not

question: Locked-in syndrome occurs due to which of the following causes?

answers.option: Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery
Rupture of the bridging cerebral veins

question: Which of the following neoplasms is characterized by a whorled cluster of cells without an obvious cell membrane?
A crescent-shaped lesion on computed tomography (CT) is a hallmark of which type of hemorrhage?

A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with vision loss. He is unable to see anything in his temporal field of vision from both eyes. A lesion of the visual pathway is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of headache and papilledema. The magnetic resonance imaging of the head reveals a mass in the fourth ventricle. Which of the following neoplasms does he most likely have?

A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive bilateral asymmetric tremors, which disappear upon performing routine activities. He has no history of forgetfulness. His attendants notice his movements are slow and sluggish. There is no history of falls, difficulty in swallowing, or respiratory problems. Upon questioning, his daughter reports a long history of constipation and sleep issues such as dream reenactments and insomnia. An MRI of the brain shows insignificant age-related changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following bacteria is a known cause of meningitis and can be diagnosed by Quellung reaction?
Which of the following is a common infectious agent found in children after contracting an upper respiratory tract infection?

A 48-year-old male comes to the emergency room, with complaints of headache, malaise, mental confusion, and vomiting. The cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a pleocytosis made up of mononuclear and neutrophils, an elevated protein concentration, and moderately reduced or normal glucose. What microorganism commonly causes chronic bacterial meningitis?
What is the anatomical localization of the structure involved in a 'glove and stocking' pattern type of neurological deficit?
Which enzyme produces amyloid beta-peptide (Aβ) through the proteolytic processing of the transmembrane glycoprotein?
Which of these is a cause of reversible dementia?
What is the cause of pupil-sparing oculomotor nerve palsy?

A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with an altered level of consciousness, and fever. His brother reports he has had a fever and neck stiffness for 2 days along with a rash on his arms and legs. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 28-year-old male came to the emergency room, with complaints of malaise, headache, and fever for 3 days and now the slightest touch is painful and produces violent motor responses or even convulsions. Negri bodies are the cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites usually devoid of inflammation. Which of the following virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods?

In patients with Parkinson disease, histologic studies suggest an imbalance in brain neurotransmitters. In contrast to normal individuals, patients with Parkinson disease have an abundance of which of the following neurons and associated neurotransmitters?

Mitochondrial dysfunction has been implicated as a contributing factor for Parkinson disease, that is caused by mutations in genes that encode the proteins DJ-1, PINK1, and parkin. What is the mode of inheritance?

answers.option: Autosomal dominant and X- linked recessive

question: A 22-year-old female presents to the clinic in the 16th week of pregnancy for a routine check-up. Her doctor tells her that her baby has a neural tube defect. A deficiency of which of the following is cited as the most common cause of such defects?
Which of the following is a primary tumor of the brain that often presents with calcification?

A 5-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with complaints of fever on and off for the past 2 months, child has a history of cough along with fever. For 2 days, the child is drowsy and has multiple episodes of fits. According to the mother, the baby has lost weight in the last two months and the grandmother of the baby has a history of chronic cough. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with complaints of high-grade fever, vomiting, and headache for the past one week. On examination, he is conscious but agitated, his temperature is 103 degrees Fahrenheit, his heart rate is 140 bpm, neck rigidity is present, and plantars are bilaterally upgoing. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 73-year-old man is undergoing a radical prostatectomy for prostatic adenocarcinoma. During this procedure, the anesthesiologist reports a drop in blood pressure with hypotension that persists for 30 minutes despite intervention with pressor agents. Which of the following pathologic lesions is most likely to occur in his brain as a consequence of this prolonged hypotensive episode?

answers.option: Linear parasagittal infarction of watershed area

question: Each cellular component of the central nervous system responds differently to injury. Which of the following statements is correct about the pattern of injury in its respective cells?

answers.option: Microglia undergo cell death by necrosis or apoptosis
Neuronal injury commonly results in hyperplasia of neurons
Neuronal injury commonly results in their hypertrophy

question: A brain tumor histopathology specimen shows cells with round nuclei with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance) associated with dystrophic calcification. What is the most likely brain tumor that exhibits these features?
A brain histopathology specimen shows pale substantia nigra and locus ceruleus with neuronal achromasia, tangles, and ballooned neurons. Which of the following diseases exhibits these features?
Which of the following is the most common primary brain tumor?
Which of the following is a characteristic histopathologic finding in Parkinson disease?
What is the mode of inheritance of Duchenne muscular dystrophy?

A 41-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with worsening weakness in his right lower limb for the past three months. He also experiences extreme fatigue and pain in his limb. He has a medical history of a diagnosis of poliomyelitis at the age of 5 years which involved flaccid paralysis of the right lower limb that improved over a period of time. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of anosmia for 5 months. Radiological imaging shows a mass in the anterior cranial fossa along the olfactory groove. A primary brain tumor is suspected. What is the cell of origin of the most likely tumor?
Which of the following is appropriate regarding histopathological features of multiple sclerosis?

answers.option: Periventricular lymphoid aggregates with CD19 cells
Perivascular lymphocytes with demyelination in white matter

question: Which type of cells are affected in poliomyelitis?

answers.option: Anterior horn cells of spinal cord

question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient clinic by his mother with complaints of muscle weakness and clumsiness. He started walking at the age of 3 years. His gait remains unstable and he experiences frequent falls. On examination, when asked to stand up from a sitting position on the floor, the child assumes the hands-and-knees position and then climbs to a stand by walking his hands progressively up his shins, knees, and thighs. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old male presents with multiple cutaneous macules, nodules of the iris, and a brain mass detected by a previous computed tomography scan. Recently, a computed tomography scan revealed an adrenal mass which prompted a visit to the consultant neurologist. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings?
Which of the following tumors crosses the cerebral hemispheres?

The first mutations identified as a cause of Parkinson disease involved SNCA, a gene that encodes α-synuclein, an abundant lipid-binding protein normally localized to synapses. This protein is a major component of the Lewy body, which is the diagnostic hallmark of Parkinson disease. What is the mode of inheritance of this mutation?

A 66-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with difficulty in getting up from his chair and buttoning his shirt for the past 3 months. On examination, no neurological deficits were noticed. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 78-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of diminished facial expression (often termed masked facies), stooped posture, slowing of voluntary movement, festinating gait (progressively shortened, accelerated steps), rigidity, and a "pill-rolling" tremor. According to epidemiologic evidence, exposure to which of the following is protective for Parkinson disease (PD)?

A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of headache, photophobia, irritability, clouding of consciousness, and neck stiffness. A spinal tap yields cloudy or frankly purulent cerebrospinal fluid, under increased pressure, with as many as 90,000 neutrophils per cubic millimeter, an increased protein concentration, and markedly reduced glucose content. Bacteria are visible on a smear. Which organism is responsible for causing acute pyogenic (bacterial) meningitis in adolescents and in young adults?
Which of the following is a commonly overlooked initial non-motor symptom of Parkinson disease?
Which of the following options include all four cardinal symptoms that are present in Parkinson disease?

answers.option: Tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability
Tremor, bradycardia, rigidity, and postural instability

question: A 66-year-old male complains of progressive problems with gait, speech, and hand tremors for two years. He also has occasional lightheadedness with standing and a 6-year history of impotence. He has no past medical history and takes no medications. His blood pressure is 140/84 mm Hg lying down, and 98/72 mm Hg standing, without change in pulse. Mental status is normal. He has reduced facial expression, high-pitched dysarthria, and mild anterocollis. There is no resting tremor. He has an irregular tremulousness of both hands when outstretched, worse on the right, without ataxia on finger-to-nose testing. He is bradykinetic and his gait is slow, shuffling, and unsteady. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old HIV-positive male has received no antiretroviral therapy. CT scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage, but there is a midline shift. MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm circumscribed and solid mass. Cytologic examination shows large cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm that mark with CD20, but not with GFAP or cytokeratin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Compared to sporadic Parkinson disease (PD), PD that is due to a dominantly inherited mutation in the a-synuclein gene is characterized by which of the following?

answers.option: Older age at the onset of symptoms
More robust response to dopaminergic therapy
The stronger association with neuromuscular junction dysfunction

question: Which of the following is the most common brain tumor in children occurring in the posterior cranial fossa?

A 69-year-old woman has exhibited fluctuating cognitive function, lapses in attention, excessive daytime sleepiness, and periods of disorganized speech over the past 3 years. In the past month, she has had visual hallucinations and memory loss. MR imaging of her brain shows minimal cortical and hippocampal atrophy. A SPECT dopamine transporter scan is abnormal. Which of the following movement problems is she most likely to manifest?

A 50-year-old male, a diagnosed case of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), dies due to meningoencephalitis. A brain autopsy shows soap-bubble lesions, and microorganisms are visible with India-ink preparation. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for the patient's condition?

A 40-year-old female presents with right-sided unilateral headaches for the past 5 months. Physical examination yields no remarkable findings. The representative gross appearance of the lesion seen on the CT scan of the head shows a dura-based mass. Surgical removal and microscopic examination show elongated cells with pale, oblong nuclei and pink cytoplasm with occasional psammoma bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
According to epidemiologic evidence, exposure to which of the following is protective for Parkinson disease (PD)?

An 11-year-old girl presents with a history of increasing headaches upon awakening for the past month. On examination, papilledema is present bilaterally. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of her brain reveals a 3-cm solid circumscribed mass within the fourth ventricle. There is a third and lateral cerebral ventricular dilatation. The mass is excised and microscopically shows perivascular pseudorosettes with round, regular tumor cells arranged around vessels. Which of the following neoplasms is she most likely to have?

A 10-year-old boy presents with a complaint of persistent headaches for the past 3 months. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows a 4-centimeter cystic mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere. On gross examination, a cyst filled with gelatinous material. The cyst has a thin wall and a 1-centimeter mural nodule. Microscopically, the mass is composed of cells that have long, hair-like processes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old HIV-positive man has received no antiretroviral therapy. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage, but there is a midline shift. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows a 4-centimeter circumscribed and solid mass. Cytologic examination shows large cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm that are marked with CD20, but not with glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) or cytokeratin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Spina bifida is caused due to the deficiency of which of the following?
Which of the following is seen in raised intracranial pressure (ICP)?

answers.option: Herniation of the temporal lobe causes third cranial nerve palsy
Infratentorial lesions produce symptoms earlier than supratentorial lesions

question: Which of the following is a risk factor for Parkinson's disease?
What is the most common neurodegenerative condition that has slow progression and causes dementia?
What type of meningioma is characterized by a whorled continuous pattern of cells with psammoma calcifications, without distinct cell membranes?
What is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in a 22-year-old male?

A 45-year-old female patient who is a known case of an autoimmune disorder visits the neurology clinic with complaints of fatigue, tingling, numbness, muscle weakness, and muscle spasms. CSF analysis reveals oligoclonal bands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

answers.option: Spongiform changes in the cerebral cortex
Loss of Purkinje cells in the cerebellum
Perivascular lymphocytes and demyelination of white matter
Tau protein aggregates in neurofibrillary tangles

question: A patient comes with complaints of difficulty in climbing stairs and walking, weight loss, low-grade fever, and solid cystic mass in the adnexa. What will be the most probable diagnosis?

A 62-year-old male patient comes with complaints of slowness of speech, and pill-rolling tremors at rest. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) would most likely show changes in which of the following structures?
